prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To estimate the amount of CO we expect in our targets we use the relation between the 100 micron flux and the CO emission for IR bright galaxis from Solomon and Downes (1997). We compute the restframe 100 micron fluxes by first measuring the spectral index between our PACS 70, 100 and 160 micron data. We then assume that the CO profile will have a width between 200 and 250 km/sec based on similar CO observations of PG QSOs from Evans et al. 2006 and Scoville et al. 2003). As we are interested in the FWHM widths only for this initial study we seek a SNR of 3-5 at the FWHM .

To estimate the amount of CO we expect in our targets we use the relation between the 100 micron flux and the CO emission for IR bright galaxis from Solomon and Downes (1997, hereafter SD97). We compute the restframe 100 micron fluxes by first measuring the spectral index between our PACS 70, 100 and 160 micron data. We then assume that the CO profile will have a width between 200 and 250 km/sec based on similar CO observations of PG QSOs from Evans et al. 2006 and Scoville et al. 2003). As we are interested in the FWHM widths only for this initial study we seek a SNR of 3-5 at the FWHM . This source has ~400mJy at 100 microns, using SD97 we estimate a total CO flux of ~1.8Jy km/sec which would imply a 7mjy peak flux that spread across 3 beams would yield a peak of 2mjy/beam. We estimate that while we may not have enough sensitivity for analyzing the CO profiles across the source, we will be able to determine and total intensity maps for our study, and hence only ask to reach a sensitivity of 0.5mjy/beam per 50km/sec channel.

We estimate the expected 1mm fluxes from our recent observations with Herschel at 100 $\mu$m. We assume that the flux is uniformly distributed in the Herschel PSF at 70 $\mu$m. From our typical SED fits (Fig 2b) we assume a conservative ratio of 35 between the measured flux at 100 $\mu$m and the predicted 1mm flux. The two sources have fluxes of 250 and 618mJy at 100 $\mu$m. From this we infer that their total 1mm flux are $\sim$7 mJy and 18mJy. Assuming that the emission is uniformly distributed in the 5.6" Herschel beam, the expected fluxes in the 0.6" beam are 30-50 mu Jy.

All the 85 sources in our sample are not surprisingly well characterized by a modified black body with a dependence on the frequency between 1 and 2. Over half of our sample is detected in SPIRE Herschel bands (at 250, 350 and 500 microns). With these data we can determine that these PG targets have a cold dust component but not its distribution. We assume that the size of cold dust emission is the PACS 70 PSF (~5.6") and that it is unformily distributed. We have followed up some of those targets with CARMA and did not detect them at the 1mjy/beam level. Here we seek to reach a 100 microJy sensivity per beam which only requires 31 minutes for two targets including overhead.

Our FIR data suggests a host IR luminosity on the order of 10^11, similar to a local luminous infrared galaxy. Its IR luminosity leads us to expect a total 12 CO (1-0) flux around 3 Jy km/sec. Assuming that the unresolved Herschel Pacs emission (5" resolution) is uniformly spread, and that the gas has widths on the order of 250km/sec across the disk, we seek to detect profiles in each beam tha peak at 2.4 mJy/beam, and hence for an SNR of 4 at the peak, we request a sensitivity of 0.6 per 50km/sec channel.

We detect this source at the 50mJY level in our SPIRE 500 micron maps. The SED leads us to expect around 15 mJY at 1mm, if this emission is smoothly spread throughout the 5.6" PACS beam it would suggest ~2mJy per 2" beam.

This source is detected to have ~80mJy with Herschel SPIRE at 500 microns. Its emission appears slightly resolved at the 70micron 5.6" PACS resolution. We thus expect around 0.8 mjy/beam for a 1-2" beam.

We estimate the expected 1mm fluxes from our recent observations with Herschel at 100 $\mu$m. We assume that the flux is uniformly distributed in the Herschel PSF at 70 $\mu$m. From our typical SED fits (Fig 2b) we assume a conservative ratio of 35 between the measured flux at 100 $\mu$m and the predicted 1mm flux. The two sources have fluxes of 250 and 618mJy at 100 $\mu$m. From this we infer that their total 1mm flux are $\sim$7 mJy and 18mJy. Assuming that the emission is uniformly distributed in the 5.6" Herschel beam, the expected fluxes in the 0.6" beam are 30-50 mu Jy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The coevolution of central black holes (BH) and their host galaxies through starbursts and AGN feedback are major elements of recent galaxy evolution models. Here we propose to investigate these processes in a sample of 5 PG QSOs, by examining how their ISM properties reflect the evolutionary stages of the host galaxy, and the mass of the central black holes. PG QSOs are ideal for such a study because there are complete and uniform data on their BH masses, SEDs and HST imaging. Here we request observations of the 12CO(1-0) transition on kpc scales, to measure the cold gas surface densities as well as the dynamic mass and gravitational potential of the host galaxy and 1 mm observations to map the coldest dust component predicted by our Herschel study. These data is a pilot program, the complete 20 object study will provide the fundamental dataset for studies of molecular gas in local QSOs by almost doubling the number of interferometric studies of combined cold dust and gas in with more than 4 times the spatial resolution and sensitivity.
